awd_titl_txt: CC* Integration-Large: mGuard: A Secure Real-time Data Distribution System with Fine-Grained Access Control for mHealth Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The mGuard project aims to address two major data access challenges in sharing mobile health (mHealth) data among researchers who investigate a wide range of health and wellness issues: (1) because wearable sensor data may expose privacy-sensitive information about a user, they should be accessed only by authorized users; currently this access control is largely handled manually, incurring high overhead and subject to human errors; and (2) to enable real-time intervention for certain medical conditions, researchers need to retrieve and process the sensor data in real-time, which is not supported at this time.

mGuard tackles the above challenges by utilizing the results from the NSF-supported Named Data Networking (NDN) initiative, in particular the solutions that automate the cryptographic key management for data access control (name-based access control, or NAC) and the solutions that enable real-time synchronization among distributed datasets (NDN Sync). First, mGuard utilizes and extends NDN NAC to automate fine-grained access control of confidential data to authorized researchers.  Second, it utilizes NDN Sync to provide real-time data production notification; based on this, it enables applications to publish and subscribe to data in real time by directly using MD2K data names. These new capabilities will be deployed in the MD2K cyberinfrastructure.
				
This effort enables the Mobile Sensor Data-to-Knowledge (MD2K) Center (supported by the National Institute of Health) to share its data securely and in real time with a large number of mHealth researchers. The transformative potential of mGuard thus extends across many types of digital interventions and many health domains. mGuard also encourages researchers in other areas of data-intensive applications to explore NDN’s data-centric solutions. To train the next generation, mGuard is creating undergraduate and graduate education materials including concrete examples and hands-on exercises, as well as training and outreach activities through online seminars, conference tutorials, mHealth training institute, and summer camps.  

The mGuard project website is https://mguard.md2k.org.  Published papers are maintained through the mGuard website, NDN website (https://named-data.net/), MD2K website (https://md2k.org), and publishers’ websites.  All of the software produced by the project is maintained in the NDN GitHub (https://github.com/named-data) and mHealthHUB (https://mhealth.md2k.org/).   Curriculum materials, program documentations, and user manuals are maintained on the mGuard project website. The trace data, simulation code, and evaluation results will be maintained on mGuard internal servers for a period of at least 10 years. Investigators will archive data, samples, and other research products, and preserve access to them at least five years beyond the project’s end date, subject to resource availability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The mGuard project addressed two major data access challenges encountered by the mHealth research community by closely collaborating with the NIH Center of Excellence for Mobile Sensor Data-to-Knowledge (MD2K). MD2K enables researchers to share mobile health (mHealth) data among researchers to investigate a wide range of health and wellness issues. First, since wearable sensor data may expose privacy-sensitive information about the data sources, it should be accessed by authorized users only. This access control is largely handled manually, incurring high overhead while being subject to human error. Second, in order to enable real-time intervention for certain medical conditions, researchers need to retrieve and process the sensor data in real-time, which is not currently supported. Our goal was to develop a system based on Named Data Networking (NDN) to support (a) automated data access control, and (b) real-time data delivery for mHealth data. 


Our 5-year effort achieved the following outcomes.

  • We developed an NDN-based system, mGuard, which enables real-time delivery of, and automates the access control to, the mHealth data.  mGuard uses PSync, a name-based synchronization protocol, to allow users to subscribe to real-time mHealth data streams, and uses NAC-ABE (Name-based Access Control with Attribute-Based Encryption) to grant fine-grained data access to authorized users based on contextual information.  We have evaluated mGuard’s performance using sample data from the MD2K project and demonstrated the system in the NDN Community Meetings held in 2023 and 2024.  The mGuard code is available to the public at https://gitlab.com/netlab-memphis/mguard-group/new-mguard.
  • We improved the security, flexibility, and efficiency of the NAC-ABE library by incorporating key-policy attribute based encryption (KP-ABE), key segmentation, and data validation, and by introducing changes in its naming scheme.  Our NAC-ABE code is made available at https://github.com/UCLA-IRL/NAC-ABE.
  • We made significant enhancements to the PSync library to address its limitations in data synchronization and improve its performance.  More specifically, we integrated the Hello and Sync protocols in PSync into a unified system, ensuring unique data stream naming, real-time update notification, and streamlined synchronization.  Our PSync code is available at https://github.com/named-data/PSync.
  • This project has supported the training of one staff member, four graduate students, and three undergraduate students in their research skills and career development.  The students and staff member have published five research papers based on the results from this project.  One of our PhD graduates' dissertation is mainly based on his work on mGuard.  Students have also participated in the annual NDN Community Meetings and organized NDN Hackathons.


The mGuard effort will enable the already successful MD2K center to share its data securely and timely with a large number of mHealth researchers. It also showcased the utility of NDN’s data-centric approach with security built-in, which will attract researchers from other areas of data-intensive applications to explore this new direction of building scalable and secure cyberspace applications.

Modified by: Santosh Kumar
